title: Tuesday, 29th January 2019
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:05am

This again. Hello. Hi. Welcome.

Blank canvas hi
VV75 morning
Mouselet Good morning assorted people
BE11:05am

Comments seem to be working again today as well, meaning we can't call the session off after three minutes. That's both a relief and a disappointment in equal measure.

BE11:06am

Where should we begin?

BornCynic Morning
Opecmoney Morning morning
11:06 am
BE11:06am

I guess with this?

Soundbuy Morning
BE11:06am

CABINET IS SAID TO BE DISCUSSING `MALTHOUSE' BREXIT COMPROMISE

Edward Quince I got a "system is temporarily unavailable" the first time I tried, if that's any consolation.
BE11:07am

Everything's coming up Malthouse!

Lawro Makes me want a pint...
Blackbag99 is it a good brew
11:07 am
BE11:07am

https://www.ft.com...-b329-c7e6ceb5ffdf

BE11:08am

Leading Eurosceptic and pro-EU Conservative MPs have been secretly working together on a set of compromise proposals in the event Theresa May is unable to secure parliamentary approval for her revised Brexit deal.

As the House of Commons prepares to vote on Tuesday evening on a series of amendments to the UK prime minister’s deal to leave the EU, it emerged that an unlikely alliance of hardline Brexit and Remain supporters within the Tory party have been working privately with government ministers Kit Malthouse and Stephen Hammond to craft a breakthrough to the political impasse.

MPs involved in the talks include Jacob Rees-Mogg, the head of the Tory European Research Group of Eurosceptic MPs, and Steve Baker, another hardline Brexiter, and the pro-EU former education secretary Nicky Morgan.

Edward Quince "secretly"
Curious I read this article on your friend & mine Mike Ashley: https://www.economist.com/britain/2019/01/26/can-the-power-drinker-of-british-business-rescue-the-high-street
PBateman Morning all
BE11:09am

And the response is ...... nothing much. Cable's $1.3153 on the bid, flattish on the day.

PBateman When this got cancelled on Friday it threw me off kilter for the whole day
mike good morning
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian What a pathetic country this is.
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Oh, but since we're deep in the slough of Brexit again, DB's Sanjay Raja has one of its UK overviews out.

Pharma @1st, feel free to sail off to a sunny Pacific island.
Manxish Morning each
Blackbag99 Thats brexit sorted for the day then
BE11:11am

We find evidence to suggest that stockpiling in the economy is underway - consistent with survey reports. Government spending for no-deal Brexit is also ongoing, though there have been no additional spending announcements since the Autumn Statement. Overall, this should be supportive of growth in the near term. As an offset, however, we seeu ncertainty negatively impacting consumer and business sentiment as households spend less and businesses cut investment.

BE11:12am

(@Pharma: don't do that. We're above that here.)

11:12 am
BE11:12am

While stock building can provide a boost for growth, on balance risks to our forecast for Q1-2019 are to the downside. Our calculations suggest that stockpiling could add between 0.1pp to 0.2pp to GDP in Q1, with this being a purely temporary (and reversible) effect. However, a deterioration in confidence may depress consumption and business investment by around 0.2pp, meaning our current growth forecast for Q1-2019 (0.3% qo-q) could be revised lower by 0.1pp. Should Brexit resolution not come soon, ongoing uncertainty could mean that our annual growth projection for 2019 could also be cut by 0.2pp to 1.4%

Pharma @BE I've heard of the Hotel California Brexit, but not the Slough Brexit. Sounds much worse.
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian If Brexit nonsense and the Little Englanders continue to dictate policy I may do just that.
T.E.L. Anyone else perplexed by the wild Crest gyrations today? -4%, +8%. What gives?
fortyeight Wake me up when it's all over.
BE11:12am

That's where we are. Economic benefits or otherwise of hoarding candles and tinned goods.

red yes more indecision and further extensions will just keep gdp down
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Hard-Brexit dead tonight, hopefully! Hurray!
Pharma @BE, sorry. And sorry to the 1st Lt. too.
BE11:13am

red but that left and right extremes can apparently get together clearly shows it pure politics
Grouchmonkey Morning
Catgotmytongue Morning
Blackbag99 "Overall, this should be supportive of growth in the near term." As a macro modeller I disagree with that. In an output model, import good model. Inventories are zero output negative output through input through trade.
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Open in new tab to make readable, though you might not want to.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Pharma - No need to apologise. I probably deserve it. :)
undefined
VV75 DUP backs malthouse alternative
BE11:15am

Okay, that's the big nonsense done. Onto the small nonsense.

rw42 Is this malthouse thing still just unicorns till the EU indicate it's acceptable?
Lawro @Laura_K_Hughes1mNEW: The DUP are backing the ‘Malthouse’ alternative. Arlene Foster: "The DUP has given its endorsement to the plan. "
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Crest Nicholson mentioned earlier.

Crest Nicholson Holdings PLC (CRST:LSE): Last: 367.40, up 25.8 (+7.55%), High: 367.40, Low: 330.00, Volume: 714.70k
Grouchmonkey CVS results give a whole new meaning to the phrase "sick as a dog"
BE11:16am

.... On a statement that profit will be at the lower end of the range.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

FY18 results in line with the previous guidance so we can ignore those. £176m PBT, 55.7p EPS, 33p DPS.

Pharma @rw42, blocking no-deal is just unicorns until the EU agrees an article 50 extension
Catgotmytongue Anything on Tobacco?
BE11:18am

The only interesting thing really is that H1 will "be difficult".

BornCynic PZ Cussons please BE
BE11:18am

Meaning Crest Nicholson will continue to step back from the London market and has postponed the opening of a tnew South East division.

red @Pharma yes you have to remember that apart from voting to revoke, anything the MP's vote on is pie in the sky unless the EU is willing to go along with it.
11:18 am
BE11:18am

And phew, eh? The last thing London needs is more houses.

Dead Cat Bounce Any grey on CVS group, getting hammered
Dead Cat Bounce ?
BE11:19am

From here, to explain the rally, you look to The Millhouse Compromise and the fact that Crest is pretty cheap relatively speaking.

BE11:19am

Here's UBS.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

We expect the shares to remain weak near term, on the back of results; however, we see downside protection from valuation with the shares trading at book value, 10% dividend yield and 6.0x P/E'19E. We have recently revised our forecasts down and estimate a -10% revenue decline over FY19-21E and operating margins around 16-17%. Our PT is DCF based, assuming LT adj. ROCE of 15% and WACC of 9%.

BE11:20am

.... who are buyers.

BE11:20am

And Barclays.

Blackbag99 hows royal mail doing
Pharma Never fear. The London Mayor is proposing rent controls, so that should help the capital's housing market.
11:21 am
BE11:21am

undefined
BE11:22am

Okay, so we have CVS, Royal Mail and Cussons stacked up in the requests. We'll get to them all, promise.

Lemmy Pharma: can the mayor implement/legislate for that?
Pharma If you want cheap housing for people, build some and rent it out.
11:22 am
BE11:22am

First though, smokes.

British American Tobacco PLC (BATS:LSE): Last: 2,487, up 111.5 (+4.69%), High: 2,514, Low: 2,440, Volume: 1.74m
Grouchmonkey Market very prone to overreaction, these days. Yes, CVS saying its harder to make money on the continent than here and growth is slowing is disappointing, but margins coming in from 79% to 76% doesn't exactly sound like a disaster to me.
Mouselet I find it difficult to think of '10% dividend yield' as a sign of anything other than imminent total doom
Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 2,436, up 74.5 (+3.15%), High: 2,453, Low: 2,361, Volume: 503.21k
Pharma @Lemmy, don't know, but apparently it's going to be his big policy for reelection.
11:23 am
BE11:23am

The first, and possibly only, thing to note here is that Piper Jaffray's buying BATS.

Mouselet pharma: and if you implement rent controls it'll be much easier to afford the land required to build the social housing
BE11:23am

We consider valuation attractive at current levels and upgrade our rating to Overweight from Neutral. We feel modestly more comfortable with glo's risk from patent litigation in Japan, especially at current valuation (current PE multiple is at a 10-year low and over 40% below its average). We are trimming our estimates on currency and more conservative US assumptions, taking some risk out of our forward outlook, but we maintain our £30 target, as we consider our 10x multiple (unchanged) to adequately discount potential risks. We trim our 2019E EPS from 301.5p to 295.0p and our 2020E EPS from 317.0p to 310.0p.

BE11:24am

Which is worth digging into a bit further.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

First, on valuation, the chart looks like this.

BE11:24am

Grouchmonkey Still can't believe vaping is so popular...
BE11:25am

PE of 8.0x to 19.0x over the past decade. Currently 8.0x.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

And part of that is the menthol discount.

BlackT any grey on Intermediate Capital please
Shinshin Imposed rent controls in London a nice warm up for a Corbyn administration
BE11:25am

To remind, about a quarter of BATS' earnings comes from menthol gaspers.

BE11:26am

Pharma @Mouselet Rent controls in New York sit comfortably with people paying $180m for a flat. But perhaps they are doing it wrong.
Finlay @rw42 anything that mentions WTO rule 24, removing the backstop, bi-lateral agreements between Ireland & UK and technology solutions have massive red flags.
11:26 am
BE11:26am

From there, you go into arguments about a menthol ban taking up to 10 years to push through the courts .......

BE11:27am

..... and you look at Canada, where a menthol ban has produced lots of interesting innovation. Including, amazingly, a resurgence of snus.

BE11:27am

Anyway, BATS divi's fine says Piper.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

We have had questions from investors on risk
to the dividend, reflecting concerns we do not share. The biggest headwinds for BAT are largely sentiment and headline related, and we still expect earnings growth (even with currency pressure). Its cash flows do not appear to us to be at risk in a way that would impact the dividend, and we consider its 9% dividend yield to be attractive.

Grouchmonkey snus?
Catgotmytongue Any info on ability to deleverage at targeted 0.4x ebit, please BE
PBateman Argument to say a good proportion of menthol smokers would switch to same brand non-menthols
BE11:28am

They also say it's a 50-50 likelihood that PMI will win a patent litigation in Japan over Glo, which would cut 2020 EPS by about 7p worst case scenario.

PBateman Still can't get over Altria paying $12.8bn for 35% of Juul
red @Mouseletfolks dont need to buy houses but you can argue smokers find it tough not to smoke. so on that levels, tobacco yields are prob safe over the next decade or so. the rest depends on asia.
BE11:30am

Anyway. That's BATS.

11:30 am
undefined
BornCynic Royal Mail letter volumes down - sign of that was my mothers living room. Used to be packed with Xmas cards and now they have been reduced to one cabinet.
wayneJ Hello. Question for the ROTR - is expenditure on cigs / vapes / drugs fungible?
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Very difficult to ignore those yields on BAT and IMB

Back to requests, and the appropriately named @DeadCatBounce wanted CVS.

red also as part of a portfolio of a couple of dozen or more ft100 yielders, u can have some real gogs in there and capital wise it will still be in positive territory before yield is considered.
PBateman Would you re-invest divs in BATS or take the money and run?
Soundbuy Breedon - healthy vols. today..........14m odd.........are we building a wall?
BE11:32am

We've been anti listed vets for some time here, mostly due to structural scalability problems, though it was concentrated on PetsAtHome .....

wayneJ Separately anyone watch the BBC 2 programme last night about Cameron and the run up to Brexit - shocking how bad the negotiations / discussions were managed on the UK side?
11:32 am
BE11:32am

Today, we get a warning from the smaller one.

CVS Group PLC (CVSG:LSE): Last: 470.40, down 182.1 (-27.91%), High: 539.00, Low: 451.40, Volume: 1.91m
red @PBatemanif u dont need income ALWAYS reinvest. over a ten or twenty year time frame the difference can be hundreds of percent

... which is largely because the move into Farm and Equine markets hasn't worked.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian "China Tobacco, like many other tobacco companies, produces a plethora of brands – over 900." - wiki 900 brands!
11:33 am
BE11:33am

They're blaming "poor support" from the pharmas and are crying foul. Fowl. Whatever. Sorry, I don't do puns.

PBateman agreed Red, but reinvesting in a business in long term structural decline?
wayneJ Surely Pets at Home and Metro Bank ought to merge - give a full service offering to pets and their owners.
PBateman year 150 you are left with lots of worthless shares and no money.. exaggerating but it's not unilever, they are selling a high margin product who's volumes are predicted to decline 2-3% each year for the forseeable
BE11:34am

Though it's not as if the core business is going well either.

BE11:34am

Industry-wide vet shortages have resulted in above inflation salary increases. (Hello again, Brexit!)

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Meaning they're increasingly reliant on locum cover, so margins get smashed.

Electric Dragon The Malthouse Alternative. The Millhouse Compromise. Lots of "Things that sound like 70's prog rock bands" today.
wayneJ @Pbateman - in fact u are left with ash in your hands, a bad smell and regrets?
Blackbag99 @wayneJ Badly managed? Everything Cameron asked for was within his own power. The mistake was to talk to other EU entities.
red asia certainly not in decline. and in any case, its addictive so will take many decades to become unviable commercially.
Finlay @wayneJ -especially the attempt to exploit a EZ crisis to gain concessions to shore up support at home. I'm sure that has lived long in some memories.
Pharma @PBateman - interesting question. Wonder if anyone has tested whether you can reinvest dividends in *any random stock*, and not just in the one you already hold.
BE11:35am

Plus we get a reverse warning over the rollup strategy.

Forester snus......working with Scandis for decades, they are obsessed with it! Technically illegal in UK but.....
BE11:35am

Acquisition multiples being sought are increasingly above levels that will deliver acceptable financial returns.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Tobacco - Population growth, consolidation, brand migration - still along way to go.
11:35 am
BE11:36am

Here's Berenberg.

BE11:36am

Possibly the most significant announcement from today’s update is that the CVS board is “re-evaluating all acquisitions and particularly the multiples it is willing to pay”. We believe that, at least in the near term, further acquisitions are unlikely. While the multiples being demanded for UK small animal deals appear to have reached an uneconomical level, the company’s attempts to diversify into other verticals (equine, farm animals) and geographies (the Netherlands) have been broadly unsuccessful, and seem unlikely to be extended. This shifts the equity story to a turnaround, requiring faith that management can take cost out of the business and manage issues of salary inflation.

PBateman the look on the hr director's face when a snus pouch fell out of a swedish traders mouth in the kitchen - not impressed
wayneJ @Blackbag - I kept on thinking that point and it never made sense to me. EU members are able to limit access to benefits and residence for those who do not have financial means etc
red @Pharmaany single stock will have differing returns, but what you can say for sure is given any particular share, reinvestment will give a large markup
Forester Most teens I know seem to regularly vape....hard to be too tough on them considering the kind of stuff we used to stick away in the good old days!
BE11:37am

There's a point in every roll-up story that you look at debt and go, "er, hang on now ...." CVS's is today.

Forester @PBateman snus is hyper-addictive!
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Without a clear strategy for the group to offset its cost inflation, net debt rising to 2.4x EBITDA at the half-year (FY18: 1.4x), and an uncertain future for CVS’s consolidation ambitions, we think that the equity story in the business is fundamentally changed. We lower our FY19-21E EPS forecasts by 20-30%, downgrade our rating to Hold and reduce our price target to 550p.

PBateman no doubt!
hornblower @Pharma - exactly. it's nothing to do with it being dividends, if you keeping adding to your investment pot every year and markets go up you will get a bigger pot, it's just maths
FATDAZ @Pharma @PB Bateman I don't know for sure but I would imagine that when people look at the compound effect of dividend reinvestment they look at a benchmark like the S&P 500 or FTSE 100 rather than its individual components - But it is a good question
wayneJ The bit that made me cry was when Cameron came close to a deal and then the narrator said: 'But there was a problem - the British Home Secretary' and then Cameron was quoted as saying re said Home Sec: 'With her on my side, I will win. She promised.'
Grouchmonkey Margins "smashed" to, I repeat 76%
BE11:38am

H1 £117m of net debt, an increase of £48m since the year-end position of £69m .......

Blackbag99 @wayneJ It was all sovereign to the UK parliament in the first place, Dutch and German Governments had already applied rules that meant a waiting period on benefits, which was within their sovereignty
PBateman reinvest works with flat stocks or gently rising stocks, but imagine the SP falls on average 3% per annum, love to know whether you'd be better off pulling the cash out and running it into the ground or reinvesting
Pharma @Forester, interesting question will then be whether they continue (being addicted to nicotine of course), or switch to cigarettes. The overpowering sweet smells from vapers seem targeted to children, like shandy vs. bitter.
wayneJ @Blackbag99 - the lack of strategic thought, planning, analysis, scenario analysis breathtaking. Confirmation that it was all in the UK's power anyway - shocking. In fact SHOCKING!
BE11:40am

(@Grouchmonkey: ebitda margin of ~12%. What on earth are you excluding?)

PBateman yield of 9%, you could pay off the holding in what 12-13 years by taking cash divs then any future divs and principle is 'free'
PBateman supposing the div holds..
11:40 am
BE11:40am

And Peel Hunt .....

BE11:40am

We now forecast EBITDA of £51m in the full year, which implies £26.5m in H2. The H2 performance will be supported by additional contributions from acquisitions and the cost savings. We assume modest profit improvement in 2020.

wayneJ @Finlay - the attempt to block a EZ rescue was absolutely inane. The whole attitude was that the EU is our enemy rather than a club where we all pull together.
BE11:41am

The company will now hold fire on acquisitions in order to focus on improving the existing operations and reduce debt levels. This alters the investment case and puts CVS at a strategic disadvantage to private peers. The shares will clearly fall sharply on this news. If so, there will inevitably be interest from the industry consolidators.

Finlay @Blackbag99, the UK didn't apply rules on benefits and access to healthcare that might have cut some Euroscepticism off at the pass. On the other hand, I wonder if the cost of administrating is actually higher than the cost of paying the minority of EU nationals that claimed.
hornblower Hargreaves Lansdown grey if there is time please
wayneJ @Finlay - nearly as bad as the EU - India trade deal being blocked by the British Home Sec of the time; who now seeks a UK-India deal - but guess what the same issues will arise.
Pharma @Blackbag99 - continental benefit and health systems are contributory. That is what makes free movement a non-issue.But how far would a UK political party get proposing a similar change here? Just look at what happened to May when she suggested an small contributory element to social care costs in 2017.
11:42 am
BE11:42am

"Industry consolidators"? Hm. The structural problems that have hit the publicly traded vet groups attempting rollups aren't significantly different to the ones faced by the privately owned vet groups, I'd have thought .....

BE11:42am

Still. Hope strings etc.

undefined
Blackbag99 @wayneJ yep it was a catastrophic mistake. All Cameron was likely to receive was a bunch of EU countries talking to their own electorate.
FATDAZ @PB bateman the studies I have seen suggest that the longer you leave the money running the better it performs though since the new millennium dividends haven't been such an important factor in US returns thanks to the emergence of mega growth stocks
11:42 am
BE11:43am

Still to come: Cussons, Hargreaves, Royal Mail.....

Blackbag99 @wayneJ But here we are!
Finlay By going to the EU and pushing for concessions on immigration it made it the hot issue of the referendum - a battle ground that remain could never win. Massive strategic mistake at the outset.
BE11:44am

Let's start in the middle.

Pharma It's funny to see everyone here discussing a BBC2 documentary about Brexit as if everything in it is incontrovertible fact.
saga Scor?
wayneJ @Pharma - it was essentially possible to do the changes required administratively without any change to end users. But easier to create a battle with the EU than look at the nitty gritty. For instance - in days gone by many hospitals collected no eligibility details for patients.
Hargreaves Lansdown PLC (HL.:LSE): Last: 1,716, down 81.5 (-4.54%), High: 1,756, Low: 1,671, Volume: 1.15m
mosschops @FATDAZ - Are mega growth stocks a new thing? Thought there was a historic paucity of new companies being formed over the last 20 odd years.
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Aha! That's the ticker. Got it in the end. So, AUM's 3% below expected.

wayneJ @Pharma - wait till we discuss the Russian funding and the.........this tea taste funny......I feel sleepy.........
BE11:46am

And quarterly fund inflows £200m below expected.

BE11:46am

Which is particularly bad because HL launched its Active Savings thing recently, which generates very little margin.

Blackbag99 @pharma as a contributory system the UK sets the minimum contribution. Not the EU, You earn benefits on what the UK government sets out
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Brexit gets the blame.

FATDAZ @Mosschops Growth in the sense that they don't really pay dividends and are focus on improving the top line so Amazon Alphabet Google Netflix et all
FATDAZ are focused on should say
BE11:47am

Have you noticed, BTW, that Hargreaves (The company) tries very hard to distance itself from Hargreaves (the person)?

BE11:47am

We are aware that Peter Hargreaves, co-founder of Hargreaves Lansdown, has expressed his views, as he is entitled to do. However, we are not involved in any way with the communications he has issued. Peter’s views are his own. He is no longer an employee or director of Hargreaves Lansdown, and he does not speak for, or represent, our views.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

https://www.hl.co....r-your-investments

Pharma @Blackbag99 - and there is no political will to change that. Just saying, if we had a healthcare system like the Germans/French/Spanish everything would be fine is no help at all when every politician has to sign worship at the alter of the NHS.
BE11:48am

Which makes it less fun than, for instance, Wetherspoon complaining about wage inflation or whatever.

BE11:48am

Here's Jefferies to summarise the moving parts.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

The effects of Brexit and volatile markets weighed on client confidence, trading activity was lower and inflows less strong than a year ago - although they remained £2.5bn positive. Market moves brought AUA down at the period end and 6% in the period, but average AUA were up 9% YoY, supporting revenue growth. The impact of lower average AUA reduction will be felt more in H2, and Brexit will continue to be a drag, coinciding with the tax year end.

BE11:49am

45,000 new clients pushed total numbers up to 1,136,000 and existing customer wealth consolidation contributed to continued inflows to the platform. These were spread roughly evenly between the quarters despite increasing Brexit uncertainty weighing on investor confidence. Total net inflows of £2.5bn compare to £3.3bn a year earlier, with the benefit of transfers from a competitor washing through and weaker sentiment. Active Savings saw net inflows of £281m in Q2, helped by an increase in marketing in September. Total AUA fell 6% in the half as a negative Q2 market effect of £9.4bn outweighed a positive £1.2bn in Q1. Closing AUA 2.6% below consensus at £85.9bn.

wayneJ I await when Wetherspoons distances itself from Tim's views....
BE11:49am

The real problem, of course, is that HL's bloody expensive.

Blackbag99 @ pharma. Would it. all 3 have a much more expensive health system than the UK
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Although facing the headwinds of market volatility and Brexit, HL has continued to attract net inflows and H2 is usually the busier half, containing the end of the tax year. The company is prepared to maintain a seamless service over the busy period complicated by Brexit. We value HL on a DCF basis and derive a 1541p PT, making it an Underperform on a valuation basis.

Pharma @mosschops, I remember reading somewhere that something silly like 90% of S&P500 growth in the past 10 years was accounted for by a handful of firms (can't remember where I saw it, so could be nonsense).
Penny morning BE and all. Just joined, anything on Kingfisher pls? Rumours of CEO departures in the Sunday's
Toolonginfinance HL need to improve their client service. Their FX rates are equivalent to going to the Post Office.
wayneJ @Pharma - the changes would have had no impact on end users - and could have been done administratively. An example - state that 1% of your taxes are for the NHS so until you have built up enough tax payment or if u have lived in the country 5 years plus etc....
BE11:50am

CY19 PE 31.4x

FATDAZ @pharam yes I seem recall stats like that too
Grouchmonkey @BE that's the staff costs
BE11:50am

For an intermediary. A rentier.

red @Finlaya win of any kind for may, even if its not her chosen amendment, puts the ball in the court of the eu, who are under pressure then not to be blamed for a no deal. they really shouldnt get something down on paper and pass it on to the eu.
Bluesky21 Top 5 stocks in S&P500 were responsible for about +1.5% in index returns in 2018
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Citi pins it even higher.

Bluesky21 Back in 2017 top 5 stocks were more than +5%
BE11:51am

At 34.6x FY19E PE, we see HL as expensive for limited EPS growth (Citi forecast 6%-7% p.a. to FY20E), Active Savings cannibalization risk (easy access launching soon) and cyclical and structural flow risk (FCA IPMS, MiFID 2 ex-post fee rate disclosures highlighting the cost of the platform to users).

wayneJ @Pharma - but u would only be able to live 5 years if you can maintain yourself. And to really encourage the Brexiteers all 'foriners' have to be registered with the local police station or mayors office within 3 weeks of arrival with all the appropriate paperwork and a desirability check
undefined
11:51 am
BE11:52am

And to Nigeria. Still bad.

PZ Cussons PLC (PZC:LSE): Last: 186.59, down 23.01 (-10.98%), High: 193.90, Low: 183.20, Volume: 437.28k
Bluesky21 And Microsoft was a top-5 contributor to S&P500 every year since 2013
wayneJ @BE - any fallout for HL from recommending certain high profile fund managers?
wayneJ Also where does market commentary pass over to guidance pass over to advice? (wrt HL)?
BE11:53am

Another warning. Nigeria spending remains terrible as the currency heads extremely south ahead of the general election.

red @wayneJother eu states manage to get by without free healthcare. those that pay in, can take out. in some cases its basic and encourages users to seek quicker results in private sector, but its accepted as the normn that only those that pay or have paid in can claim care.
BornCynic Slide 3 of the PZ Cussons presentation is fun reading.
GBKrona @wayneJ - direct read thru to AJBell - looks like the shrewd Mr Bell went public just in time??
11:53 am
BE11:54am

There's also disruption at a port that'll cost a pretty incredible £5.5m.

BE11:54am

All of which means Cussons' Africa will be lossmaking, which undermines the rest of the group. Here's Caz.

FATDAZ @GBK re AJ Bell doesn't a lady run the show there
wayneJ @red - agreed; but my point is that Cameron could have achieved what he wanted by making administrative changes without even having to visit the EU. It was a miscalculation of ginormous consequences.
BE11:55am

PZ Cussons has reported adjusted PBT in the first half of FY19 of £32.8 million, up 1.5% in constant currency and in line with our estimate of £32.5 million. EPS was 0.9% higher y/y at 5.67p (JPMe: 5.26p). As expected, Europe and Asia delivered positive growth in earnings, but this was offset by reduced profits in Africa – a function of the very challenging consumer environment and logistical situation in Nigeria. With conditions in Nigeria showing few signs of improvement, PZ Cussons has guided to full-year adjusted PBT ‘towards £70 million’, which causes us to lower our estimate by 13% from £80.8 million to £70.6 million. Our estimates for Europe and Asia are unchanged, but we now forecast a £5 million operating loss in Africa rather than a £5 million profit. We lower our Dec-19 target price from 240p to 210p and stay Neutral.

Guidance for operating profit has been narrowed to £500m-530m for the year (previously £500m-550m, we are £503m, consensus is £509m). However, we estimate that addressed mail volume declines accelerated from -7% in the first half to -10% in Q3, with the company saying that it now expects FY 2020 volume declines to be outside its normal 4-6% range as well. Although parcel growth continues to hold up (+6% volumes and revenues for the 9M), the acceleration of the mail volume declines will leave the outlook for 2020 in doubt and increase pressure on management to take more fundamental action to stabilise the business.

Davy:

BE12:14pm

In our view, Norwegian’s equity balance was likely to sink below its covenant level in Q1 and, as such, a resolution of some form was necessary. As IAG stepped away from a bid and an aircraft joint venture had not yet come to fruition, there were increasing expectations of a rights issue (similar to Q1 2018). This issuance gives Norwegian flexibility, while it looks to deliver much needed improvement of its operational and commercial performance.

12:14 pm
BE12:15pm

From an operational perspective, the company will focus on: (i) a cost reduction programme (#Focus2019 is expected to reduce costs by a minimum of NOK2bn); (ii) optimisation of the base structure and route network; (iii) the December 2018 agreement with Rolls-Royce related to compensation for the operational disruptions on its long-haul operations. Further detail will be provided on these at Q4 results on February 7th 2019.

RBC:

12:16 pm
BE12:16pm

There are hints of change - to lower growth rates, more focus on profits. If really seen, this might reduce overall market capacity growth and lead to a more rational European backdrop.

Profit focus helps all: We think NAS will now likely continue to operate for 2019 - which may reduce consumer concerns and lead to it discounting less. More rational, less distressed pricing will likely help the entire market, we think. Thus we estimate that a smaller Norwegian seat growth rate with more rational focus would be constructive to the entire industry's margin prospects. Though yet to be confirmed, a growth rate slowdown and a base pull-back will likely benefit airlines with the most overlap with Norwegian's irrational growth to date [evidenced by its loss margins] ....
